documents.title: Pipeline Overview
documents.content: The NFR Connect Pipeline is a comprehensive data ingestion and processing system designed for enterprise-scale non-financial risk data. It provides resumable uploads, schema validation, delta-based ingestion, and ML-powered enrichment.

documents.title: Architecture Overview
documents.content: flowchart TB subgraph Upload["1. Upload Layer"] TUS[TUS Resumable Upload] BATCH[Batch Tracking] end subgraph Validation["2. Validation Layer"] SCHEMA[Schema Validation] SPLIT[Table Splitting] PARQUET[Parquet Generation] end subgraph Ingestion["3. Ingestion Layer"] DELTA[Delta Detection] VERSION[Versioning] DL[Data Layer Tables] end subgraph Models["4. Model Execution"] NFR[NFR Taxonomy Classification] ENRICH[Enrichment] EMBED[Embeddings] end TUS --> BATCH BATCH --> SCHEMA SCHEMA --> SPLIT SPLIT...

documents.title: Supported Data Sources
documents.content: Data Source Files Required Description Status Controls 1 CSV file Key Performance Controls Inventory (KPCI) data Active Issues 4 CSV files Audit, Regulatory, Restricted Regulatory, Self-Identified issues In Development Actions 1 CSV file Issue action plans and remediation tracking In Development

documents.title: Stage 1: File Upload
documents.content: Files are uploaded using the TUS (resumable upload) protocol, ensuring reliability for large files and unstable network connections. Key Features: Chunk-based uploads (5MB chunks) Automatic resume on connection failure File size validation (minimum 5KB) Extension validation (.csv only) Batch session grouping for multi-file uploads

documents.title: Stage 2: Validation
documents.content: Uploaded files undergo comprehensive validation: Format Parsing - Column headers and data parsing Schema Validation - Column types, patterns, required fields, allowed values Table Splitting - Single CSV file split into multiple normalized parquet tables Multi-Value Parsing - Comma-separated fields expanded into junction tables

documents.title: Stage 3: Ingestion
documents.content: Validated data is loaded into the data layer with intelligent change detection: Delta Detection - Compare timestamps with existing records Versioning - Create new versions for changed records, preserve audit trail Relationship Linking - Connect child tables to main records via foreign keys

documents.title: Stage 4: Model Execution
documents.content: Three sequential ML stages enrich the ingested data: Stage Purpose Output NFR Taxonomy Classify records against risk taxonomy Risk theme options with reasoning Enrichment Generate summaries and complexity scores Structured analysis Embeddings Create vector representations Semantic search capability

documents.title: Monte Carlo Simulations
documents.content: Monte Carlo simulations provide probabilistic estimates of risk metrics through repeated random sampling.

documents.title: Methodology
documents.content: The Monte Carlo approach generates thousands of possible outcomes to estimate the distribution of risk: $$ \hat{\mu} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} f(X_i) $$ Where: $\hat{\mu}$ is the estimated mean outcome $N$ is the number of simulation iterations $f(X_i)$ is the outcome function for sample $i$

documents.title: DICE Model Integration
documents.content: The DICE (Data Insights Clustering Enrichment) model automatically maps control failures to the appropriate taxonomy nodes: $$ P(\text{taxonomy}|\text{event}) = \frac{P(\text{event}|\text{taxonomy}) \cdot P(\text{taxonomy})}{P(\text{event})} $$ Where: $P(\text{taxonomy}|\text{event})$ is the probability of a taxonomy classification given an event $P(\text{event}|\text{taxonomy})$ is the likelihood of the event under that taxonomy $P(\text{taxonomy})$ is the prior probability of the taxonomy...

documents.title: Impact Analysis
documents.content: Impact analysis in NFR Connect quantifies the potential consequences of risk events across multiple dimensions.

documents.title: Quantitative Assessment
documents.content: The total impact score is calculated as a weighted sum: $$ I_{total} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i \cdot I_i $$ Where: $I_{total}$ is the total impact score $w_i$ is the weight for dimension $i$ $I_i$ is the impact score for dimension $i$ (1-5 scale)

documents.title: Capital at Risk (CaR)
documents.content: For significant events, NFR Connect calculates the Capital at Risk: $$ CaR = VaR_{99.9%} \times \sqrt{\frac{t}{252}} $$ Where: $VaR_{99.9%}$ is the Value at Risk at 99.9% confidence $t$ is the time horizon in days 252 is the number of trading days per year This metric is used for regulatory capital allocation and stress testing scenarios.
